sp.p: Say you so, If you make me so happy I will—

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: No more but be gone.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Let me not live if I fail to—

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: Why do you stay so long?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I go my Trico.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Cupes this day promised to assist me, I have told him all; see where he comes with his basket of books in his hand.

div.head: The Third SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: They plot how to disguise themselves so handsomely as to personate Torcol, and the servant of the Lawyer Ignoramus, and to be sure to remember the Horn if Ignoramus comes himself. Cupes having received eight crowns to make his scolding wife more tractable, doth promise most solemnly his utmost diligence. Trico goeth to provide Ornaments, and disguises for Cupes and his VVife Polla.

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: BOoks, Books, who buyes my books, new books, witty books, witty and new, new and true, come who buyes my books, new books new!

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: You! books, books!

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: O Trico, I will come to you presently. As I live, I have most pitiful books here to day.

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: I cannot sell one of them; prethee stay a little.

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: Make hast then.

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: Come! who buyes my books, here is the Eele or Grigg of Equivocation, or of the Art of lying confidently cum privilegio, by the Reverend Father in the Divel Andraeas Belzebub, and Johannes Cydonius; come who buyes my books? who buyes Belzebub?

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: No body.

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: I will sell them to you almost for nothing? for three souce, two souce, one souce, half a souce, a un-grand Diable.

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: Have you the Divels club?

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: The Divels club— let me see— there is such a book, but it is prohibited, what would you do with it?

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: With that Divels Club I would beat out the braines of Andreas Belzebub the Divel of Divels.

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: Tut, you could not hurt him.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: His Head and Face is all of steel; Come who buyes my Books; who buyes my book of the way how to hold the Eel of Equivocation by the tayl.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: By the tayl, by the neck as well; I will buy it, by and by.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Come my fine Books. Pellio the Skinner, versipell Pellio or the way of turning the skin by Pellio himself.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Prethee name that Pellio no more, lest he spoil our Comedy, as heretofore he did the Comedies of Plautus, It makes my heart ake to think of him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I am no body to day.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I would I had his skin stuffed with straw.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Straw! Hold thy peace. I tell thee Strawes make saints now a dayes; will you have the Apology for Garnet: There is a conceited straw for you.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Cupes; There is some hope that you and I may be saints also.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What hope Trico?

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Because we are such very reprobates.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Come, my brave books. The Canonizing of Saint Garnet, of Saint James Clement, of Saint Rauiliac, all three from the Vatican Library; Here is Schioppius, the Night Owl, Come who buyes Schioppius.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Not one buyer all this while— O wonderful!

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: The flatterer or Schioppius, the art of flattering; A manuscript.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Let me see that book: Fie upon't! how it smelleth of the sloven that did compose it? he wrote it with his own Urine.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Come who buyes, who buyeth it, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Enough— you now have read over all your rank poysons.

sp.speaker: Cup,
sp.p: Would these pamphlets were all burnt for me, what have I done? what have I said? that they should undoe me with these paultry pamphlets.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Take heed how you trade in them for the time to come; O Wretched writers! O Generation of Scriblers, Incendiaries, Disturbers of the World, Insuarers of the People; Destroyers of the Nobility, Murderers of Kings, and Advancers of the Pope.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p:
Away with them all? the Annalls of Volusius, mais quoy
vanno via manniconia; but I have some books here worth any money; Here is the Prologue Caballin, or the Metamorphosis of Messe Davy, also his milleloquy at supper. The tilting of Messe Davy, and his Syn-Coriatical peregrinations.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Both he and his books deserve to be tossed together in a blanket.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But now, behold my books. Cupes of the art of drinking, inlarged, revised and purged from a hundred faults, together with an Addition to it, and a Commentary on it. Cupes de cupediis.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Doth so poor a man as you love Delicats?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I hate these grosse fed Parasites, when I have money, I feed on nothing but choice meats, and daynties.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But Cupes, Cupes, long not for Phesants you have scarce two Farthings to buy a half penny Loaf.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Why, I may have a good mind to them for all that.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And why so Cupes? Are you a Cupedinarian?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I was one heretofore, I have been of a thousand professions; when I was a young man at Paris I was a player.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Thou hast made me happy then; for this day thou art to act the part of many persons.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: At Venice I served a Confectionary; there I made Wafers, Marchpans, Macaroons, Suckets, Dry and VVet, and all manner of Sweet-meats.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: There you could lick your Fingers.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But that which I most affected was at Tholouse, where being servant to a Vintner, I fragally sipped every day three or four Gallons only of Wine, till at the last my master broke; after that I ran away into Holland where I carried about an Ape with a Gay Coat on his back; at Rome I was leader to a blind man.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He gave you therefore but blind obedience.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: At Rome? why? He who is most obedient there, is most blind.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What did you do in England?

sp.speaker: Cup
sp.p: O la bonne terre d' Angleterre; I first was there a Sowgelder in the Country; afterwards I was an under Butler in the Inns of Court amongst the Lawyers.

sp.speaker: Trico.
sp.p: Were you ever in Spain?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: VVhy not?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I cannot be contented with three Raisins for my Supper Trico.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: 'Tis well, but do you remember, what I told you of, even now?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I do, and I promise to perform it, by putting on a disguise to personate one Torcol.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But with a crooked and a distorted Neck.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Why thus! how do you the posture?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Admirably.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Afterwards I am to counterfeit the servant of a Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But if Ignoramus comes himself, be sure you do remember the Horn.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Remember it, I will warrant you; not any one of them knows me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And thus disguised you will be the more unknown; but you must teach your wife also how to personate Rosabella, she is apprehensive I know, and will be apt to follow your instructions.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: She is, but I am affraid I shall not be able to perswade her to it, she is so unreasonably obstinate, and alwayes scolding, nay she will beat me also.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: VVhat is she a Fury?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: A Fury Trico; she is all the Furies in one.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: If I had three such VVives I would give two of them to the Divel upon a Condition.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: VVhat condition Trico?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: That he should take away the third.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Let him take her.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But I will give both her and you, that which shall overcome you both, look you, here is eight pieces in Gold.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Give it me, and I will bring my Dame.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I conjure thee Cupes by thy bowels.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You have conjured me by that which is most dear unto me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: That you will be careful in the performance of this.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: It shall be done.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I will go and procure the cloathes and properties for you and your wife. Be you alwayes waiting here to prevent all inconveniences, and to provide a Remedy upon every Emergency.

sp.speaker: Cupes.
sp.p: I will, but this night we will sup together; it shall be a night of mirth.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Your words are full of Hospitality, may all things prosper with you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Farewel, I will now call forth my wife and overcome her with gold; for without that she will do nothing: I know she will scold as her usuall manner is; she is alwayes muttering and murmuring, like a Weesil crushing the bones of a Mouse; Polla! wife Polla! why Polla I say.

div.head: The Fourth SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Polla at the first rants it, but having received the gold, she flatters her Husband; And if Cupes, in the mean time, will bring no Wenches into his House, she promiseth that in other apparrell she will personate another woman, and so be delivered to one whose Name is Pecus.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: POlla, Polla! what a hooping and a hollaing is here? what are you got drunk again?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I would I were, my Polla, I have not drank one drop of wine this day?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Why dost thou stand so idle here thou swilling-tub? Hast thou sold any Pamphlets this day? Hast thou got any money thou drunken Sot, thou?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Not a farthing.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: How! I shall—

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Would the pamphlets were all burnt, and the writers of them hang'd for me.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p:
And thou hang'd with them, sometimes thou pawnest my
Books, sometimes my Cloaths to the Vintners in their Taverns.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: 'Tis true my Phillis, I have done it, and thou hast soundly Cudgelled me for it.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I have, and will soundly Cudgel, and Cudgel thee again. Shall I sit spinning with an empty belly all day at home, when you in the Taverns are all in a hoyt, dying the pavements with Claret Wine and Muskadine; but if ever I see you set but your foot again within a Tavern.—

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What? not so much as my foot.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I have said it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Then kill me without any more adoe; But clear thy brow, my Dear, what wilt thou drink Sweat-heart! tell me my Love!

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Away with these flatteries; If my Cloaths be not redeemed—

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Sweet Love, they shall be redeemed, look thee what here is—

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What Gold! where didst thou get that Gold sweet Man?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Now I am your sweet Man. O Gold what canst thou not do? will you have half of it?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Yes my dear Soul.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Dear Soul! O thou most dissembling Woman! well, you shall have half, if you will do me one small courtesie.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What is it?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Nothing, but a little to put thy self forth to a Friend of mine to use thee.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: O wicked man; what wilt thou put forth thy wife to use, thou thy self knowing it?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You do not rightly understand me?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What, if I should now make thee a Corn-elius of a Cupes.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I would then make thee again a Corn-eliu of a Bolla.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Tell me what sayst thou? hadst thou rather be Publius Cornelius, or Cornelius Tacitus?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Oh, Cornelius Tacitus by a great deal, but I think no Man will make a Whore of such a pittiful Jade as thou art, Ha, Ha, He.

sp.speaker: Poll
sp.p: Pitiful Jade; Dost thou laugh at me, thou ugly Tankerd-bearer?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: No lovely and fair; I do not laugh at you, you do much mistake me.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What dost thou mean by it, tell me then?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Canst thou in another Habit personate another Woman.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Is that all? very easily.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: And make a surrender of thy self to one Pecus; he will neither tempt nor force thy Chastity, never fear him?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Fear him? shall I fear any one Man who have beaten a thousand?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Me, I am sure on't, you have full often.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Well— give me the Gold, and I will warrant thee my Cupes; Never doubt it?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Look you here then? here are two pieces for you; after you have effected your businesse, I will give you two more.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Agreed, but on this condition, that in my absence you bring none of your Wenches into my House as your usual manner is.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: O vainly Jealous! Why I sleep always with you, all night long?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: You sleep indeed, I had rather that you should wake by half, but if I take any of your Wenches in my house; by Earth and Air, and the Heights above, and the Deeps below—

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: O swear not downwards.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I will drag them out into the streets by the Hair of their Head, where I will so belabour them, that they shall not be able to stir a Foot.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You shall never find me with any.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: On that condition, I will assist thee according to thy expectation.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Let us go in my Phillis, where I will give thee more full instructions.

div.head: The Fifth SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT:
argument.p: Antonio, and Trico do borrow cloaths of a Broaker, and for a pawn they give him a Brasse King with a counterfeit stone in it, Cupes goeth to make himself ready.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: THe plot you told me of pleaseth.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Pyropus, the Broaker will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But what pawn shall we give him for the cloaths we are to have?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You say well.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have given you all the Money I have.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Have you no Rings, nor Jewels?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: None at all.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But Trico, Master, hath a Ring.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: A Brasse one peradventure.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But double-gilt with a brave stone in't.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Some Counterfeit I believe.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Pure glasse Sir, finely cut and painted; it sparkles so, that any may may be deceived with it.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Trico, Let me see it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Put it on your finger, and pretend that you value it at a very great rate; It is ten to one, but he will swallow it: St, no more words, here he comes himself— save you Pyropus.

sp.speaker: Pyro.
sp.p: Save you Sir; Come hither Boy, and show the Gentlemen the Cloaths you have brought.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Quickly; for I am in great hast at this present.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Come— sirrah, dispatch; what a fumbling do you make; Give them me; Look you Gentlemen, There is no man in all Burdeaux that can shew you better, or hath more choice.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Master This is a very good suit to travel in.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: But observe the fashion, and the workmanship of it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Cupes shall wear these, and Pollo these; And this shall serve for the other.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: I have brought all you told me of.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well, well, go too— give us the price?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But onely for one dayes wearing.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Shall I be at a word with you verily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Dispatch then.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Shall I be at a word, verily shall I be at a word with you?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You kill me with delayes.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Well— Verily and indeed la, you shall give me Forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Forty shillings.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: You cannot give me lesse verily.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Verily saith well Master.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Yes verily.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Pray Sir then make short with verily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Well— I will give it.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: I do value them all at fourscore pound.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: The man verily saith well.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: If you cannot spare so much money, let me have but a sufficient Morgage.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: And Verily▪ what needs that, my Master being one of the chiefest Merchants son in all the City?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: What do you doubt me?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: No Sir; but the Custome of our trade expecteth some security.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I have a Ring on my finger which I value at a very high Rate.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: What, that Master, with the rich precious stone in't?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: The very same.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: 'Tis worth at least three hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Let me have that?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What, a Ring of so great a Value; How shall I be sure to have my Ring again?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: I have a shop verily.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He hath verily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You will not trust me being a Gentleman, why shall I trust you being but an ordinary Trades-man?

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: I know not what to say more—; pray give me my Goods again!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Master you may trust him, The Man is an honest Man verily, I have known him along time.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Do you know me verily?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Yes verily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Upon your word I will trust him with it.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Verily how it shines, and glisters, and sparkles?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It doth verily flammasque imitante Pyropo.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, God be with you?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Let your Boy first convey these things for us into the next Lane, and leave um—

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: At what Sign?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: At the Sign of the Anchor.

sp.speaker: Pyr.
sp.p: He shall verily.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Farewel my Fine City-wit verily.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I hope now that all things will answer our expectation; But what if Ignoramus should now come himself—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: We will fright him hence; Be you but vigilant and lie close, and we shall doe well enough.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I will be all eyes my Trico.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And I and Cupes will lie in Ambush here.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But what if I light upon my Father?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I presently will instrust you how to circumvent him. Go and make your self ready.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: If any thing falls out crosly, you must with patience endure it; for Fortune sometimes will faulter.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Be no bad Prophet Trico.; Fortune I hope will assist us, but make what hast you can unto me; for without you I am but a blind-man without a Guide.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I will be with you again immediately. Doe you hear Cupes, Cupes, Take these Cloaths, and presently attire your selves.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: It shall be done in an instant.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: But whom see ● here? my best and familiar Friend Milsalis▪ He promised to assist me; I peradventure may drain something from him as often heretofore I have done.

div.head: The Sixth SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Musaeus complaineth of Ignoramus, and what a slavish life he leads with him. He propounds him in a Riddle unto Trico, and informs him, that Ignoramus is coming with six hundred Crowns, Trico sends Musaeus to Antonio, and Cupes, to acquaint them with it.

sp.speaker: Musae.
sp.p: I Would my parents had broke my neck when they first placed me to this Fool Ignoramus; Let me say, or doe what I can to please him, he is alwayes exclaiming against me; How ill favouredly doth he carry himself? This is my fine schollar; he neither knows how to put a Bridle on a Horse, nor to ride him, being bridled, nor mend a broken Girt; where are your Syllogismes now, you Vniversity-Coxcomb?

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Musaeus how do you?

sp.speaker: Musae.
sp.p: Well Trico, were it not ill with me in having so bad a Master; I would he had his due for me.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Musae.
sp.p: He doth so torment and confound me with his babling.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Why, Is he not fluent, accurate, and eloquent?

sp.speaker: Musae.
sp.p: There be others indeed that are so, but he is nothing lesse; he doth all things so perversly, he puts his Cap on his Feet, and his shooes on his Head.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: O most ridiculous!

sp.speaker: Musae.
sp.p: Trico I will read thee a Riddle, and do you solve it?

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Let me hear it.

p.hi:
What is that which liveth by Right, and by Wrong, which hath a great Heart and no Heart, which is both an Ambidexter, and a Bifront, which speaketh Much, and speaketh Nothing; which is Jest in Earnest, and Earnest in Jest; which speaketh English, Dutch, French and Latine, yet speaketh neither English, nor Dutch, nor French, nor Latine; which writeth Lawes that they may be misprisions, and which writeth misprisions that they may be Lawes,
which maketh a Finite Infinite; Truth, no Truth, and no Truth, Truth.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Which maketh Truth no Truth, who should this be, but Belzebub Cydonius?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It is he, and it is not he.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Who loves to speak in an unknown Tongue— It is A Popish Priest.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: It is something like him, but not the same.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What a Blockhead am I? now I have it.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What, or who is it?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It is your Master Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Mes.
sp.p: You are an Oedipus.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Who was Father to this Monster?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Francus Soloicophanes, his Mothers Name was Barbara Latina.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Where was he born?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: In great Puritania.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: In what City?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Either Aurelia, or Argentina.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What doth he feed upon?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: The Common Law.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Is he not Learned? Doth he not know the seven Liberal Arts?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: The Seven Arts! why, I tell you, he knows all letters.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Good God! what all letters?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Why— There are but four and twenty Letters in all.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He is a Man of a Thousand!

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p:
Certainly there are but few such as he is; Every Order neverthelesse hath both good and bad, both wise men and fools; In good corn there are some bad ears, and in bad some good ones; It were foolish therefore and inhumane (although many are guilty of it) to inveigh against whole Societies and Orders, and the studies of many Men for the extravagancies of some few persons; If need were I could number up many excellent Men of this Order so transcendent for Wisdome, Learning, and Piety, that they are hardly to be parallel'd, who have both learnedly expounded, and sincerely delivered the Laws of their own Country, then which there is nothing more just, or righteous: These
Men we alwayes prosecute with deserved honour; for they proceeded from us, and are for us. No man is an Enemy to Learning but Ignoramus; Let Ignoramus therefore and such as he are, who desire the Ruine of the Church and Universities—

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Be for ever banished.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Nay, let them go into Morbonia.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: They will be angry with you.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Ignoramus will, but no man else; but what he thinketh or thinketh not, is all one to me.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: To bring such a man upon the Stage were dangerous.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: Not at a jot, why all the world is but a Stage where every man's a player.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Come Musaeus we grow too serious, Tell me what is thy Master Ignoramus now about?

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: He is coming unto Torcol; He hath told the Money just now.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I came on purpose to acquaint you with it.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: And why with a pox no sooner? make all the hast you can to Cupes, and bid him be sure to remember the Horn.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: What Horn?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: VVhat is that to you; He knows already what is to be done, let him immediately acquaint Antonio with it, let them be both in a readinesse.

sp.speaker: Mus.
sp.p: I fly, may some evil fall on Ignoramus, I heartily do wish it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: If he comes not immediately away,— the whole plot is spoyled, Woe is me, Ignoramus is come already.

div.head: The Seventh SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Ignoramus brings the six hundred Crowns which he bargained for Rosabella, Trico the more to delay the time untill they can be dressed in their disguises propoundeth a ridiculous case in Law to be pleaded by Ignoramus, which when he insists upon longer then ordinary, Trico, to requite his patrons courtesie, acquaints him what Antonio hath contrived against him, and that he had sworn to geld his Rival Ignoramus wheresoever he could find him.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: HEre is the legem pone, Here are the six hundred Crowns, which just now I intended with Torcol, for my Sweet-heart Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He hath brought the Money, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: If I live, Rosabella my stella d●nsab● veteres mensuras, I will Dance my old measures with thee.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: They have watched him well—

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: This is the Indenture, and the Obligation of Roderigo Torcol, I will go to him in propria persona.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Out upon't,— what makes them stay so long? I must detayn him with some discourse or other— Save you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Sirrah who are you, Hah.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A poor man Sir,, that hath spent all his Estate in Law.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Oh, oh; In forma pauperis, Abi via, Abi via, Away, Away.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir I crave your Counsel.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: My Counsel Knave, Legem pone, Legem pone.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: We must give a Sop to Cerberus, what shall I do? I have some brasse money about me, I will sling it away on him; Sir I am a very poor man.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: A poor man— That signifies nothing.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But because Sir, you are well vers'd in Causes, I must beseech you to hear my Cause, And what Money I have left is here at your service.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Oh well, well, Have you joyned Issue?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Issue— What shall I say now?— yes Sir, Issue, Issue.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Declare?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: My Grandfather Grunnio, the son of Bore, had an Uncle called Hog.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Quondam Uncle.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You say right Sir Quondam Uncle, but the Quondam Uncle of the Sister of my Quondam Grandmother, who was Cousin German, to the Grandmother of my Quondam Father.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Well said Quondam; Alloons.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Did bequeath unto me a black Horse; the truth is, he had but a short come off: why shall I dissemble? he had no Tayl, but what then? should any man put a Nettle under it?

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: In Tayl speciall, In good Earnest by Right he could not do it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He did neverthelesse, but he did. VVince and Kick, and fling his leggs aloft.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Take heed of that.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And he kill'd the Deer and Phesants.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: O Dammage Faisant Here must be a demur.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And certainly the Kalendar lyed abominably; for I well remember it did Hayle.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: A good circumstance, and which maketh for you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Slow man of Burdeaux▪ what not yet— Sir? And he not only put a Nettle under his Tayl, but he repleated all his mouth with pepper.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Repleated? a replevit will not serve in this case.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: So I thought, but he having before his eyes the Figure or copy of a white Horse.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: O— What Copses too, it is in tertio Richardi primi potest Copitias Toppare, Loppare, & abscoriare, He may Top them and Lop them, and do what he will with them.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He did not though— I lost him that year, who can help it— what do you think of it Sir— Snayles! we are undone.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: What do I think of it? was not that black Chevall your Chattle personal?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Chattle, yes Chattle indeed, but I am affraid of the pepper Sir.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: You say well and there is the point indeed; for this is your case, If John an Oakes in●eoffat John a Stiles de Black Acre, and John a Stiles capit Black Acre & VVhite Acre, in this case Tout is void, All▪ All.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I think they are asleep— But the pepper being snuffed into his Nose did make him stand an end on his Leggs before, and break wind backwards.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Snuffing, and Leaping, and petting is a good Tenor doubt it not.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But I am still affraid of the pepper.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: What need you fear. But take out a subpena for him, and if he doth not return black Cheval, and white Chevil cum costis ad pinguebus dammagis, with costs and ●at dammages, say that Ignoramus non habet Lex.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Farewel, For I have some businesse must be dispatched.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But Sir, For the good Counsel you gave to me, I have some good Counsel, to requite your love, for your self, And what much concerns you. If you are Ignoramus, make all the hast you can away, Fly and be gone.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Hah— Fly wherefore?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You love Rosabella that liveth here hard by.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: VVhat then?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Antonio also is deeply in love with her, and in my hearing did swear most seriously that He would dismember Ignoramus wheresoever He could light upon him.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: It was but in Jest.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But do you get you gone in Earnest, and have a care of your self; for that most dissolute Cutter hath gelded very many that I know of.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: You have put me in a bodily fear, and because I am in a strange place, I am in a greater doubt; look yonder Fabula est in lupus.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He comes at last.—

div.head: The Eigth SCENE of the Second ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT:
argument.p: Antonio Enters full of threatning, Cupes within sounds a Horn, as if he were a Sowgelder, Ignoramus hides himself, but being discouered he had much to do to escape the affront of being gelded; but having sworn that he would never come to Rosabella again, he was permitted to depart. Antonio goeth to a Painter, to paint him a little Mole on his Cheek, which his Father observing may conceive thereby that he is not Antonio, but Antonine newly come from London unto Burdeaux.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: WHere is that old Whoremaster Ignoramus, who would defraud me of my Love? If I serve him not as I would a Hee-goat—

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Do you hear now?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Doth he use to be as good as his word?

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: He never breaks it.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: He is not Compos mentis, I will have a Breve for him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I have brought the Sowgelder along with me, he will be here presently.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Client Trico, I am in a great fear Client.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Trin— Tran. Cupes within sounds his Horn like a Sowgelder.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I hear him now.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Trin— Tran.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Client Trico, Tremblo, tremblo, I tremble all over, what shall I doe?

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I hear him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Trin— Tran.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Hide your self here behind me, lest they discover you quickly, quickly, and as covertly as you can, quickly I say.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What do we stay for? I have all things here in a readinesse, Look you here else.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: Friend, do you hear? Did you not see a Lawyer hereabout?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Say I am gone to London?

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: He is gone to London.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: I heard he was here but just now.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Say I am gone home— then.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: He is gone home.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: He shall not so escape Ile warrant him.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Client, go sidelong, that I may make an escape.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Close, close.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Something goes yonder, what is it?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Here he lies, Lawyer! How dare you be so bold?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Shew me your Testatum est latitare.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: But you shall have but little to show before I have done with you, Let us go in with him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Come to the Court Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: I command you in the Kings Name to keep the peace.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: You prattle in vain.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He is my patron, I beseech you Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: You pray in vayn.

sp.speaker: Igno:
sp.p: What do I pray? what will you not look upon the Almanack first?

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Why? Upon my Honesty you will find the Sign in Scorpio.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: 'Tis full of Danger then.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Take heed what you doe, If I die within a year and a Day—

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Your words move us not.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: What will you judge me non audita querela?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: No, no, you shall be judged by your peers.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I beseech you Gentlemen, I beseech you for him.

sp.speaker: Anto.
sp.p: If we should let him go, he would presently come sneaking hither again.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Client Balliato me, pray bail me Client.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: I will engage for him that he shall come no more.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: I swear most solemnly, If ever you find me here again—

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: What do you run away?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Follow him, follow him, whither runs he.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: I am safe and sound now, titillabo vos, monstrabo tricum de lege, I shall tickle you for this isaith, and show you a trick of the Law; but because I have sworn, I will not go my self, but send my Clark Dullman for Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: He is gone, he he.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: Ha, he, he.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: Ha, he, he.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You are gallant Watchers, How well did you attend his coming?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I was ready, and at hand, and heard all your discourse till I was ready to burst with laughter.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He is now possessed with such a fear, that he will send his servant, do you Cupes therefore and your wife attire your selves in such habits, that you may be taken for Torcol, and he for Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I go, it is done me thinks already.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Master, and let us be jogging too, I will tell you in the way the rest of the fallacy, I must go now to the painter, and take you along with me.

sp.speaker: Ant.
sp.p: What shall we doe with him?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He shall paint a little Mole in your Cheek, Let us go, I wil tell you what you shall doe if peradventure you shall meet with your Father in the way.

div.head: The First SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Whiles Antonio in painting the Mole in his cheek, Trico proceedeth in his deceits; Dullman cometh with the Indenture, and the Crowns to take away Rosabella, he asketh Trico of the Portugal; Trico makes answer that the Portugal with his wry neck is his Master, and shews him the verses which Ignoramus gave to Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I Have well instructed my servant Antonio, the Painter is now painting the Mole upon his Cheek.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I see here no body, but by the Masse I am in a great fear, for there are many Ins●n● Pilei, called Madcaps here in Burdeaux.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What Bird have we here!

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: My Master Ignoramus swore that they would make a Gelding of him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He is a stranger.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: A fine Riot, was it not, to take away our instruments.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He holds the writings in his hand.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: My Master therefore gave me a letter of Atturny to take s●l●in of a certain Virgin called Rosabella, whom I never saw.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Certainly this is Ignoramus servant; Cupes, Cupes are you in a readinesse?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: At hand quoth pickpurse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here is the servant of Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I see one yonder, I will demand of him, if he knows his messuage to whom I go; my Master said he was a Porsugall with a wry Neck, I have no other knowledge of him, Hoh, honest man,

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Who would you speak with Friend?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: He is a man of a good behaviour, I would speak with one whose name I do not know, do you know it?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What a Blockhead 'tis? of what Country and complexion is he?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: He is a Portugal,

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: With a wry Neck?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: So they say.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Tis ten to one, but tis my master.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: It may be so.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Do you remember the first letter of his Name?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Puto, facio, I believe I do.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Doth it begin with a B?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: A, B,— No?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: With G?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: G— No.

sp.speaker: Tric.
sp.p: With R.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: R,— No, No.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: With T?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: T— stay ● yes, T, T.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Torcol.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Torcol, Torcol, A pox on't; I have his name here in black and white; are you his servant?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Yes Signior,

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: In bono tempo, what is your Name?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What shall I now say— Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Mendoza; in bono tempo.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And what is your name, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Dullman, the Senior Clark to Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Dullman Clark to Ignoramus, in bono tempo, have you brought the Crowns with you Dullman?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Six hundred Mendoza, and the Indenture with them.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: In bono tempo, Do you know whose hand this is?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I marry do I, It is my Masters hand.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Tis right, he made these verses on our Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Pimpillos, pursos, ad ludos ibis & ursos; Right, Right, you say very well, they are his verses indeed, I would I could make such, but I pray you call your Master hither, to tender a Delivery of Rosabella to me.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: He will come presently.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Est hic honestus sodalis warrantizabo. An honest good fellow this I will warrant him; I would Rosabella would come with him, I seem for the present to be in a Forrest, I do so fear the Tax of Horngelt.

div.head: The Second SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Cupes enters with a wry Neck counterfeiting himself to be Torcol, and to carry on the deceit more handsomely he speaks some Fragments of the Portugal tongue; they both of them deceive Dullman, and fish out of him the Indenture, the Crowns and the sign whereby Torcol might be assured that he is Ignoramus servant.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: LOs Diablos te gannan picar●, you Rascall have you no more manners in you?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: This is the Portugal with the crooked neck; I conceive him to be, but I am sorry he is so impatient with the poor man his servant.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Sirrah can you not bring the friend of my most honoured Lord (save you Signior) into my house, you Rascal, that he may tast a cup of Wine after the English Fashion.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: There is no such fashion in our Countrey.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Trunkan Villaco! what stand you still, and dumb like a dog? where is Diego? where is Alonzo? where is Piedro? where is Guzman?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I know not Master, I.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You know not Master! just so I thought, but I shall—

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Master Torcol I pray, noli chafare propter me: chafe not for me I pray Sir, your man is a good servant truly.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: A good servant with a Halter— but Signior have you brought— have you brought Signior?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Ovy, Ovy dea, yes, yes, Signior, my master hath sent you here six hundred Crowns.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: So he is bound to do, you Sirrah? watch-I-call, you— Mendoza!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Here Master.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Tell the Money?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Here is your Indenture also, look you Sir, here is your own hand, and your own Seal to it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: (He looks upon it) Hum— Roderigo Torcol; it is as you say.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Deliver now Rosabella to me for my Masters use.

sp.speaker: Cup
sp.p: Stay a little— and first tell me what is the private token which was agreed upon betwixt your Master and my self?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: You say well, and that no Breve Erroris be here committed, I am injoyned to give you a sound tweak by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: By the Nose Seignior?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Your Nose must come into the Court Nasal, and pay Homage Nasative, come Sir, ha, ha, he, My Master is such another merry Man, come Sir Here I have it, I faith now.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I know it was the token, I only had a desire to know, if he had given you any Item of it, it is the token in earnest.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Yes in Earnest.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: I have told the Crowns, but this is a good on?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Current upon my life.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Tis well; Friend what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Dullman, And your servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Well! Take this for thy pains, and be Dullman still— Nay take it I say. Bring me now Rosabella hither, and a Flaggon of the most generous Wine; Sirrah do you hear, bring also some Sack with you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What would you have Sir?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Sack you Villain, according to the English Fashion; Sack I say, wellcome Signior.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Indeed Sir it is needlesse, est postremum quod feci; it is the last thing I did.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Nay what do you mean, mend your draught I pray, you shall you have a cup of Sack too, my friend Dullman.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Est valde curtesius homo. A Noble, and a courteous Gentleman I'le warrant him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Desire your Master for my sake to love my Rosabella well, I brought her up for my own Daughter; my heart doth earn within me to think of her departure from me, but I am confident he will be very tender over her.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: You may assure your self, she shall receive all the courtesies that the customs and Country of England can afford her; my Master will give her a good Joynture, I know it well, for I have ingrossed it, but I pray deliver me the counterpane of my Masters Indenture.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: On my troth I left it with my Notary, but presently I will either bring it, or send it to you.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Then give me an acquittance.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Do you hear (sirrah) Bring hither some more Wine and Sack, where is this Knave now?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Veni presenter post me quaeso; I pray you Sir make hast after me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I will Dullman.

div.head: The Third SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT:
argument.p: Polla is introduced weeping and disguised, and is deliverd to Dullman for Rosabella; Dullman is dismissed full of wine and sack.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: DO you understand me Polla?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Is it not possible for you to hold your tongue?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But be sure you have tears enough in store.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: No more; for on my faith,— if you provoke me!

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You muzzle me to a silence.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Look! Here he comes.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Deliver her unto me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Rosabella my dear Cosin, nay rather my Daughter, I here deliver thee to this Man, that he may conduct thee to thy Husband. And must thou now leave me my Dear? I cannot forbear from Tears for my own part; but do not afflict your self, if you love me.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: My Uncle, nay rather my Father; although I shall be Married to another, and though it be never so well with me, yet to leave you—

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You do increase my Tears.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: Oh Dullman, Maudlen Dullman, who can refraine from weeping?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Not I truly.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: No more can I Dullman. Well— you have got a Mistresse of a sweet disposition.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Certe videtur tenera & amens pecia, quanquam maskata est; She seems indeed to be a very loving and tender piece although she is masked.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: It is the custome altogether for Virgins in these Countrys.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: And a good custome it is.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But on better considerations, we should rather rejoyce then weep to see her well Married.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: And you say true by the Masse.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Why let us be merry then.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: You speak very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Shall us laugh?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Shall us drink?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Wine?

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: If you please.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: And good Sack too, Seignior Dullman.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Even what you please Sir; I am prepared to pledge you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Well then— Give us some Sack! Here is to you Seignior Dullman.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Some more Sack, Fill it up according to the English Fashion, Fill up the Glasse I say; 'Tis sweet Sack, my sweet Signior.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: So, so; Ad te Magister contra es dispositus, Sir unto you against you are disposed.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I thank you, you do but sip; drink deeper, where's this Varlet? some more Sack for my Friend.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: I have done very well Sir, I must now take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: God, buy good Signior, Good, buy, sweet Cosin; I shall long to hear how you thrive in the world.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: God, buy, God, buy.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: God be with you Master Mendoza.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But my dear Signior, take this one Glass before you go.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: And with much thankfulnesse; I will drink your health in England for this.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Dull.
sp.p: Farewell, Quam curtesii; How courteous are these Men of Burdeaux.

div.head: The Fourth SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: In this Scene Cupes withdrawes himself to put on such cloaths as he may be taken for Dullman himself, and speaks broken English, such as he learned in England when he was under-Butler in the Inns of Court.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: TAdepole, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Farewell, Sacksop, Farewell.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: He knows not of what cup he drinks; intemperance hath often disgraced the high atchievements of the English in their wares.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: More Sack, more Sack, you Rascal! How sweet it is; Give me leave to kisse thee my mingle?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: No more of these reiterations, I will now go, and put on other cloaths, and counterfeit my self to be Dullman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O, Sack for Dullman, you know the sign.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: If I do not soundly twinge him by the Nose let me—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I will take the Crowns along with me, and this writing.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Writing! Indenture, Trico, I remember that word, and many more ever since I was an Underbutler in London, I have many of the Lawyers phrases still by heart.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am confident, the Pandar Torcol doth not know Dullman very well.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: And me much lesse.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Why, if you are taken, you can tell a handsome lye for your self.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I have learned that out of the books of the Jesuits, and will give place to none but Belzebub Cydonius.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: My proteus, we loose ourselves in vain discourse; I will immediately addresse my self to Torcol, and pretend I come with Counsels and Conditions very advantageous to him; and as you see occasion, do you intervene?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I will attend the Scene with my best dilligence.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: We being thus united shall circumvent him with the greater dexterity of deceit.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I go to attire my self.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And I to Torcol, I am affraid he is not at home. Tick, tock, Tick, tock, he knocks at the door.

div.head: The Fifth SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Trico endeavoureth to circumvent the pandar Torcol who will give no ear unto him, as knowing very well what Trico is; at the last Trico seems to be angry, and doth curse him.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am a Prophet; my mind gave me that Trico was here, and here I find him.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Signior I love your Maid Surda, I love her most intirely.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You love Surda, Go, go, I am now awake.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But now Sir I come unto you on businesse of importance which deeply doth concern you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: O Signior you cannot deceive me Signior.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I deceive you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You spoke it this morning.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I spoke it but in Jest.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: But I in earnest I will be careful of you, go about your businesse, go when I bid you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I have but three words to say unto you, hear me I pray you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I can hear nothing, especially of Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What hurt did I ever do you?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Nay then? VVhat good did you ever do me; when I see you, I see Dammage and the face of Destruction.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You will believe me by and by, I do assure my self.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Indeed, I shall not.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I come now unto you with a gallant condition.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: What have you any gold or silver for me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Ready coined Signior.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Farewell.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Stay a little! after Antonio understood that Rosabella was to be given to Ignoramus, being scarce master of himself, he laid throughout the whole City for money, at the last he borrowed of a Friend a Cabanet full of Gold and Jewels.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: A meer invention.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He will morgage it unto you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Trico, what do you make of me? do you think I do not know for what you come?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Do you think, I come to cousen you!

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: O Trico, you who have Gold, and Jewels, and yet have no Monies; as much Money as a man hath in his Chest, so much reputation he hath.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: What! I come to deceive you Signior;

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: If you could I believe you would.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Six or seven of the chiefest Merchants in this City shall passe their words for me.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: It is all one; your tricks shall not deceive me Trico, and to be short with you, I must tell you that Rosabella is married to Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: O Man of Men; it is now coming out—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Thou wicked man, thou sink of all Vices.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You prevaile nothing: I pray leave me?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Why what's the matter with you?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I pray be gone.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Signior.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: It is in vain Signior.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Thou monstrous piece of crookednesse.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Now rayle at me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And if I be not even with you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: What? do you threaten me?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: M. be. M. be.

div.head: The Sixth SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Cupes in the habit of an Inkman pretends himself to be Dullman, and Torcol both by his habit and his language, doth conocive him to be the servant of Ignoramus. Trico endeavours to take him off from Torcol, that so he might the lesse suspect the contrivance of the plot; but Cupes having delivered the money, and the Indenture unto Torcol, and given him the private token which was agreed upon betwixt Torcol and Ignoramus (which was that he should pinch him by the Nose) although Trico did forewarn him for that purpose, he was hired by him, yet he is admitted to Rosabella to take her away; Cupes goeth to observe Ignoramus.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: THou are very conceitedly attired Dullman in the habit of an Inkman.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I and you see, I have not forgotten to carry my pen in my ear, look you here, come, let us go my little Dullman.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: May I speak now with Surda Signior.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am deaf Signior to that proposition; but what man is that yonder?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He hath the face of a stranger.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I would fain understand what Countryman, & who he is.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I would beseech you Signior that you would understand what more peculiarly belongs unto your self.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I see a good observation for a Treveller, and I will write it down.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: He is some Traveller (as I conjecture) and observeth I know not what my self.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He seems to be a fool. How he gapes, and stares about him, and carrieth his pen in his ear.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But where shall I find him; I am so sorry I have lost my direction.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: By his speech and habit he should be the servant of Ignoramus; I think he hath his writing too.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I know not who it is.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Who?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: An Englishman living in this City, my Friends Friend; do you go in and I will accost him.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Trico begins to smell the businesse, I will now stay.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Hereabouts he said the messuage was

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: It is the very same whom I expected, he comes according to my wish.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: It is Ignoramus servant, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: He hath smelt the Game, and lost it.

sp.speaker: Tri
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: How pale he looks.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You Sir?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Come hither?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Friend a word with you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: By your leave Sir, I believe I am the man you look for.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Sir, I shall give you better satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I presume your businesse is unto me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Who is it that you look for, ask of me, and I wil resolve you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Nay rather ask me? let him come to me, why do you hinder him?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Which of you can certifie me, where is the messuage of a certain Portugall

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: A Portugall said you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I can certifie you, it is not here; the Portugalls dwell a great way from this place.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Take no notice of what he sayes, he will deceive you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Cur me mockatis ita, qui moccat moccabitur, why do you mock me so, he who mocketh shall be mocked again.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Trico, Trico, you cannot be too hard for me; you see this is Ignoramus servant, and faine you would withdraw him from me; I see it plain enough.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Now he is vexed; I am glad with all my heart it was my fortune to be here.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Estis fl●utatores ambo ego ibam viam, you are both flouters, I will be gone.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Come to me Friend, whom do you look for?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Who does he look for? what's that to you? pray go about your businesse, I am able to answer him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I look for the Portugall Merchant.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: He looks for me.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: For you? he does not— Friend.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: How gladly would you glose with him

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Follow me, and I will bring you to his house.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What doth this fellow mean?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, stay a little.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Follow me I say, and in the way I will give you Wine and Sack, good Sack boy.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What Sack?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, Wine, and Sack boy.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: By his Physiognomy I perceive, hic est nebulo in grano; this is a Knave in grain.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You may be sure of it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: A venegance on't, you are the man? how doe you Sir; by my troth Sir I scarce knew you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: This is excellent.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You know me? do you take me to be a noverint universi?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Did you never know me in England, look on me?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I shall look on a Knave then— Sir I look for such a man as you are with a wry Neck.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He looks not for you Signior, but for such another man as you are, a friend of mine, and I will direct him to his house.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: This is very likely, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You take this man to be Ignoramus servant, he is no such man Torcol.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Who 〈…〉 I come from my Master Ignoramus, with an Indenture and six hundred Crowns; what doe you behind me? why do you kick me? cur joggas, & noddas, why doe you jogg, and nodd, and wink on me so.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, Ho, so.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Do I touch you, do I wink, or nodd on you, you Asse you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I am to crafty an Asse for you.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Ha, he, Now he is mad, now he gnasheth his Teeth.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You Ignoramus servant? I know you are not, Come— lets go to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: With a murrain to you, what have you to do with me? why do you make signes, and wink, and nodd your head so?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Do I?

sp.speaker: Tor
sp.p: All the dumb Rhetorick of your motions will not prevail Trico.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: By your Neck and fashion, you should be the man whom I do look for.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Do you know his Name?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: It is, it is—

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Who is it?—

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Now I perceive it is not he, he knows not my name.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But I have it here in the Indenture.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You have— if I had met him a little sooner, how easily he might have been prevented.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I have his name here in the Indenture; it is Rodrigo Torcol.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Right.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Are you the Man?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am so.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He hath swallowed the bayt, hook, and all? but what is your name Friend?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Dullman, at your service Sir, I bring you a message from Ignoramus Sir.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Where is the Gold? where are the Writings?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Here is the Indenture, see your hand seal.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: This Indenture made the Nineteenth day of April, betwixt Ambidexter Ignoramus on one side, and Rodrigo Torcol on the other, Hum, Hum, Signed, Delivered, Hum, Hum— Rodrigo Torcol, Hum, it is as you say.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Trico is stark mad now; but what private token have you besides? I would have no man make a mouth at me?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: A mouth— No, it is your Nose that I demand; Let your nasute Nose Nasative, come into the Court, and pay Nasal Homage; he tweakes him by the Nose.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Oh gently, gently I pray, oh, oh, oh.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Is not this the token? he drags me by the Nose about the stage.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Oh, oh, yes, it is the Token— Oh what do you mean! Oh, no more I pray.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: You thought I did not know it.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: But I find to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: 'Twas only for a good Memento.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Do you not perceive, you fool, how he mocks you, and leads you about by the Nose like a Bear.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: No, he who hath no Nose is led about by the Nose; is it not alotted for every man to have a Nose, I have one Trico.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I see you will be cousened.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Be cousened; you are mistaken, you may see I will not be cousened.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You may remember that I told you this morning.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: That you would deceive me, I remember it very well.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: You do?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Yes, ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I do cousen you at this very instant.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: At this instant— sure you don't.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: I tell you this man is not Ignoramus servant.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You do not here me say, he is, do you— Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: He is a mear Cheat.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Indeed.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: And one whom I hired on purpose to deceive you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Are you sure on't?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Upon my faith I speak the truth.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You do.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Yes, and you have not the greater care, he will take Rosabella from you too.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: This is strange that you will not believe me, when I Swear unto you.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Swear no more— I believe you Trico— I believe you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: This is a good Nose, I will ingrosse it.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Upon my faith, I do cousen you now, now, at this very instant.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You cousen me upon your faith now?— is not here so much Gold? Are not here the writings? did he not tell me the very private token we did agree upon? how am I deceived Trico;

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: But take heed it be not Aurum Tholosanum.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Upon my credit it is very good Gold, & all in Rose Nobles

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: What?— am I cousened now?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Yes, and 'tis I have done it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What will you stand prating with him all day long; deliver Rosabella to me?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: It shall be done immediately.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: For I have a great deal of businesse at home to ingrosse Agreements, Quibbles, Indentures, Pilicocks, and Callimancaes.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: But tell me, what was't I pray, that even now you wrote down in your Almanack.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Oh ho, only a travellers observation; I wrote down in my book, that on the fifteenth of May I saw a Portugall with a wry neck so apparelled, and that he being a cunning Knave would Cousen you; I will put it in print.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: Note it well.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But Signior, with Rosabella you ought to give me the Counterpane of my Masters Indenture.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: You shall have both as soon as I have told the Gold; let us go in.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Are you going you seed of all wickednesse, accursed sacrilegious Caytiffe.

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I am deceived, Trico, I am deceived.

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: Trico may be even with you for all this Signior: Remember it?

sp.speaker: Tor.
sp.p: I will remember it Signior; I am going now to Surda, will you command me any service to her Signior?

sp.speaker: Tri.
sp.p: M. be— Dor, m. be— he, ha, he, the more caution the cautelous do use, the more they are deceived; but I must now be gone to observe Ignoramus, least he comes before Cupes leads away Rosabella; Afterwards I will repair to Antonio. That Mole on his Cheek doth extreamly please me, with one deceit thus I do Coyn another.

div.head: The Seventh SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT:
argument.p: Cupes bringeth Rosabella to his own house, and locketh fast the dores, and hasteth away to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: HEre is the Counterpane of my Master Ignoramus his Indenture; ha, ha, he, I have made a pure mouth of him.

sp.speaker: Rosab.
sp.p: But tell me I pray you in earnest; will you be as good as your word, and bring me to Antonio?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: If thou wilt my Girl, I will have thee my self.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Although clouded under many sorrows and misfortunes, I would have you to know (whosoever you are) that I am not discended of ignoble parentage, And though I am poor, I have yet a dowry, which is modesty, and ingenuous manners.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What do you boast of modesty in a Bawdy house?

sp.speaker: Rosab.
sp.p: As the beams of the Sun are not defiled on the Dunghil, no more are chast minds amongst unchast persons.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Ha, ha, he, women are like to Venice-glasses; keep um with all the Care that may be, and lock them up, you cannot keep them from breaking, they are but brittle ware.

sp.speaker: Rosab.
sp.p: My Father was a personage of Honour, and brought me up accordingly, And this man my Uncle, although a wicked man, yet he hath not violated my Chastity.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But I cannot bring you to Antonio presently.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Deprive me then of my life, and cut my throat.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I had rather carry you back to Torcol.

sp.speaker: Rosab.
sp.p: O, doe not, I beseech you; For he, kept me of late bound with cords, he now will use me worse; if there be any thing of ingenuity in you, kill me outright, and I shall take it for a Courtesie.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Be of good courage, I spake all this while but in jest, I will bring you to Antonio presently.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Mock me not I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: So God shall help me, I speak the truth unto you he will be at my house presently.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: O Hope unlook'd for!

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Let us hence least we be taken; Do you go in there?

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Deal civilly with me! pray you.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I willing good earnest; I will lock the dore, and by and by I will return unto you again; I will now to the Tavern, and refresh my self; This day I will dedicate to mirth with wine and good cheer, but I will first change my cloaths in the next room.

div.head: The Eight SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Ignoramus receiving Polla for Rosabella, beateth Dullman, who runs away; he groweth afterwards outragious with Polla, who could not abstain from fighting with him, and departing from him, acquaints the whole parish that he is possessed with an evill spirit.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: MMaster, I cannot find Dullman.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: No; Facias tuitissimum, & clamerum post eum, Do you hear Sirrah, make a Hue and Cry after him.

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: I think he is run away.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Cause him to be attached Pecus?

sp.speaker: Pec.
sp.p: It shall be done Master.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: What a misprision, what a Deceit is this? In the Divels Name who art thou?

sp.speaker: Polla.
sp.p: I am Rosabella, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Rosa-bella, Rosa Diabla; without doubt thou art some Ribalda that liveth in Tiplandis, & lupanaris.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I, a Ribald that lives in Tipling houses, and Bawdy houses, I would have you know I am Rosabella, aliàs bella Rosa, Seignior.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: You, a sweet Flower? you a Rose? you look like an old Cow, your Face I am sure on't, non concordat cum Recordo.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: For all that I am Rosabella, my Seignior.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: By your face I should swear that you are a Hag, and a Hobgoblin.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: You speak such strange hard words Seignior, I cannot understand them.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Do you not understand them, I tell you then again you are a Sorceresse and an Inchantresse.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Ha ha he— Do you call me Witch and Inchantresse?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Do you laugh, I will indite you for a Sorcerss as you are, viz. That you Spinster (I shall learn your Name) not having the fear of God before your eyes, but seduced by the Instigation of the Divel, have practised the wicked Arts of the Divel, vocates Witch-craft and Sorcery, in, upon, and against the person of Ambidexter Ignoramus. Ponam te super patriam si vivo, As I live I will put you upon your Country.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What sayes my Dear?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: My Dear— off with your hands— you ride in the air super broomas, on brooms and staves.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: My Dear Love— why are you so angry with Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: O ho, Are you still Rosabella? I am not compos mentis I; in good Faith I think I am bewitched in good earnest, Why do you glote so on me? I feel something within me, I know not what my self. But if I can but first draw bloud of her I do not care, I will adventure it; but I dare not doe it: But I dare though: Putana de Diabolo.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Forbear a little till I put off my Sandalls.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: I will scratch thee for a Sorceresse as thou art.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What do you threaten me? Nay then have at you, Ile teach you to strike a woman again, you base hen-hearted fellow!

sp.speaker: Igno
sp.p: Oh so, what vi & armis, & manu forti, some moderate mercy I beseech you, At least so much fair play as leave to rise again.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I will paint your face, you wizzard you.

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Keep the peace, Keep the peace? O for a supersedeas de non molestando!

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Am I not Rosabella now? what say you?

sp.speaker: Igno.
sp.p: Een who you please— O Lord, I am maimed, I will to the Office presently and have an appeal for blows and maims.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: The Divel's in you I think.

sp.speaker: Ign.
sp.p: Well, well— sum vade brusatus, I am horribly bruised, I will een go home, and say my prayers, but you shall repent it, you Sorceresse.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Do you Chatter you Monkey? Upon my faith I believe he is possessed with a Divel. He speaks Magick words too; I will be jogging to my own house and desire my Neighbours to have a Care how they keep him Company; but see my dore is shut, I did ill, that I took not away the Keyes with me, but some body peradventure is within, I will knock, Tic Toc, Tic Toc.

div.head: The Ninth SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Polla coming home, and finding the dore to be locked, and Rosabella at the window conceiving her to be her Husbands Lemmane, goeth amongst all the Houses of the Victuallers to look him out.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: WWho is there? what would you have?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Why— This is handsome, is it not? A strange Woman demands of the Mistresse of the House who she is, and what she would have? Nay then— who are you? and what have you to doe in my House with a mischief to you?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: The Master of the House will be here presently himself.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: This morning I even read my own Fortune, This is my goodly Husbands, goodly Harlot.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Speak more civilly. I am not I, for that filthy trade of life.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Was this the businesse that he so suddenly commanded me out of dores to bring this creature in? What will he keep his Whores here before my own eyes? shall I live to endure this?— Thou whore of all whores I shall presently be with thee.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Speak not so ill of me, I am not that creature which you suppose me to be.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What in my own House? was it not enough for him to wast my portion in Taverns, but he must whore it away also?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Oh, woe is me, woe is me! To what a man have I intrusted my self?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What? do you weep you Baggage? but I will make you, and them, and all of you weep, and by and by; O that I could break the dores!

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Woe is me— this woman is mad.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I will go over all the Taverns in Burdeaux, but I will have him; Oh that I could find a good handsome Broomstaffe to revenge my self upon him; Oh that these Nails were a little longer. Exit.

div.head: The Tenth SCENE of the Third ACT.

argument.head: The ARGUMENT.
argument.p: Polla finds Cupes with a Victualler singing a Song of her and laughing at her, she soundly beats them both and the Fidlers that were in the room; she throws down on the ground the Capons, Pheasants, and much other good cheer, she poures out all the wine, and having got the Key of her House, she throwes Rosabella out of dores for a whore, who poor wretch knows not whither to go.

div.stage: Cupes, the Victualler, Fidlers, Polla, Rosabella.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: OH happy Holy day— Things answering my expectation so successively, I have bought much good Cheer, I have hired Fidlers to make me more merry; But why are they not come yet? O my Priests, these sacrifices you offer, these Wine and Capons are very acceptable to me your God. O you Capons, Pheasants, and Partridges, how do I love and honour you? you are of the Nobility of Birds? how richly, how magnificently are you cloathed? how greedily do I wait upon you? as for Ducks and Geese, and such kind of Fowl they are clownish and rustical I care not for them.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p:
I have found him at last. Hay day— what a Banket hath
the Knave prepared for his Whore, I will here obscure my self, and listen a little to him.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: O my Beloved fat Friend, my dear Capon, how fairer art thou then my wife Polla?

sp.speaker: Polla.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: How willingly do I kisse you? what a sweet kisse is this? much sweeter then the kisse of my wife Polla.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What do you prefer a Capon to me, I shall speedily be with you!

sp.speaker: Fidl.
sp.p: Sure you have some foul slut to your wife Seignior.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: And I shall meet with you too.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: A foul slut— there is nothing like her; she is a Goblin, a Gorgon; Styx, Scilla, a Hydra, a Harpy, a Monster all over.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What shall I doe, I am not able to contain my self!

sp.speaker: Victu.
sp.p: Cupes, Let us sing that song I pray of your wife Polla.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What? that which I made in the Tavern, the other day?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: The very same, Let us have it I pray you.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: What have they made a Song of me too? wo is me▪ but— indeed, woe unto them.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Let us sing it.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: But what, if she should over-hear us?

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: What if she should?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: She is a roaring Lioness, I had rather dwell with winter, or the Northern wind then with her.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: You speak truer then you think for, you shall feel me thundring presently about your ears.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Begin I pray.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: I will first look if she be not lurking hereabouts to observe us; I tremble when I think on her.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: St, I will hide my self that they may not see me.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Here is no body; Now my Minstrels, for a sprightful fit of Mirth? let us have it?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I See! I am become a Song throughout the whole City; but I shall inchant the Chanters by and by.

lg.l: May Polla wife to Cupes break
By some happy fall her neck;
And may all wives that like her be
Perish so, as well as she. They all laugh, whooh, Ha ha he.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Oh for a Thunderbolt to confound them all at once.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: Come once more;— May Polla wife to Cupes break &c.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I can forbear no longer, Ile break your neck if I can.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: She hath kill'd me.

sp.speaker: Vict.
sp.p: What shall become of me? O my head.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Woe is me, O my neck and shoulders.

sp.speaker: Fidl.
sp.p: I am sore all over.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: This is a new Song for you Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Fidl.
sp.p: I am undone, she hath broke all my strings, my livelyhood is lost, what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Why do not you sing now?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Fidlers sing Lachrymae?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Do I appear so foul a slut unto you? Hagh.

sp.speaker: Fidl.
sp.p: Oh me, Oh me. Exeunt Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Must I be sung about Town by such a Kennel of Rascals? Oh that I had a little more breath, How I would be labour them?

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: If any man should ask me now, in what place of the world I am, I am not able to tell him, I am so confounded with amazement. Will you drink any Wine my Hony?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: My Hony, my Gall, will you drink to me, and invite me to Supper with a Company of Whores?

sp.speaker: Cu.
sp.p: You have thrown away all our good cheer, have you any Imperiall missives that you act so uncontroled? if you are a good woman, restore us our Victuals again; what do you spill the Wine too? I am undone— At least spare that;— woe is me, Look on that Flagon yonder, How it vomits forth its purple soul. Kill me Polla, that would be pardonable, but it is unpardonable to kill the Wine.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Now go call your Whore to that Supper she is worthy of.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: Upon my life, Wife, she is no Mistresse of mine.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Give me the Key, Give it me, I say, I will break open the dores else. Here will I make a way for my fury to enter in.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: She is deaf with Rage; I forgot to tell her before hand, that I was to bring Rosabella to my own House.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Whore— Come out of my House— Come out of my House you Whore.

sp.speaker: Rosa.
sp.p: Woe is me, whither do you throw me?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Into a Bawdy-house, the only place fit for you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Good woman I am innocent, and you are much mistaken in me, whither you will have me go?

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: To Bridewell you prostitute.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: I had rather you should kill me.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: Get you gone you whore you, Get you gone?

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.p: Woe is me, I go, I hope unto my Grave.

sp.speaker: Cup.
sp.p: What have you turn'd her out of dores? you have undone me then; It is Rosabella, and not any that I make love to.

sp.speaker: Poll.
sp.p: I shall pluck your fair Rose— you wish my death you Rogue you.
